text: The algorithm is irrelevant - if you know that string comparison is way more costly than integer comparison it just seems more sensible to use ints. As you have said before, premature optimisation can be costly but doing things that you know are faster is just good practice surely. It is like years ago, using pre-increment operators was faster than post-increment operators. Nowadays if you view assembly code for either the compiler will spot what you are doing and there is no difference but there used to be.

elements.text: The algorithm is irrelevant - if you know that string comparison is way more costly than integer comparison it just seems more sensible to use ints. text: Basically I know what takes time to execute in my code, and converting string lookups to integer lookups wouldn't save me 0,01% of the processing time. Good design is how you gain performance. I have a pipeline threading framework so even if running hundreds of threads there is no thread contention. Immutable objects that can be shared across thread with no copying is the biggest performance gain I have made in the last couple of years

elements.text: Basically I know what takes time to execute in my code, and converting string lookups to integer lookups wouldn't save me 0,01% of the processing time. Good design is how you gain performance. I have a pipeline threading framework so even if running hundreds of threads there is no thread contention. Immutable objects that can be shared across thread with no copying is the biggest performance gain I have made in the last couple of years

text: Some of <@U0128E7BEHW>'s comments from yesterday made me think about my default programming habits and whether they were right. For example I tend to do try/except in place of an 'if' conditional where I expect the condition to almost always be met, e.g. try X/Y except ZeroDivisionError instead of X/Y if y > 0. Is this a bad habit or a good one? I've obviously picked it up somewhere but is it well founded?

elements.text: Some of

's comments from yesterday made me think about my default programming habits and whether they were right. For example I tend to do try/except in place of an 'if' conditional where I expect the condition to almost always be met, e.g. try X/Y except ZeroDivisionError instead of X/Y if y > 0. Is this a bad habit or a good one? I've obviously picked it up somewhere but is it well founded?

text:
Where benchmark.py is:

```import time

import betfairlightweight
from tqdm import tqdm
from tqdm import trange
from betfairlightweight import StreamListener

trading = betfairlightweight.APIClient("username", "password", "app_key")
listener = StreamListener(max_latency=None)
stream = trading.streaming.create_historical_generator_stream(
            file_path="/tmp/1.172557162",
                listener=listener,
                )
gen = stream.get_generator()
# Warmup
number_of_market_books = sum(1 for market_books in gen())
start_time = time.time()
for _ in trange(10):
    for market_books in tqdm(gen(), total=number_of_market_books):
        pass
print(time.time() - start_time)```

elements.text: Where benchmark.py is:

import time

import betfairlightweight
from tqdm import tqdm
from tqdm import trange
from betfairlightweight import StreamListener

trading = betfairlightweight.APIClient("username", "password", "app_key")
listener = StreamListener(max_latency=None)
stream = trading.streaming.create_historical_generator_stream(
            file_path="/tmp/1.172557162",
                listener=listener,
                )
gen = stream.get_generator()
# Warmup
number_of_market_books = sum(1 for market_books in gen())
start_time = time.time()
for _ in trange(10):
    for market_books in tqdm(gen(), total=number_of_market_books):
        pass
print(time.time() - start_time)

text:
So maybe i'm not understanding the concept correctly.

The data description for `PPWAP` is "_... of all bets placed pre-off."_
The data description for `MORNINGWAP` is _"... of all bets placed before 11AM GMT"_

My understanding is that _PPWAP_ includes all the bets made pre-off which includes the morning bets. So in my understanding makes no sense to have a _MORNINGWAP_ greater than 1 and a PPWAP equals to 1.

greater than 1 and a PPWAP equals to 1.

hello, I've got a question about betfairlightweight. I wanted to implement a Timer function that calls some betfairlightweight functions but apparently Timer and threading functions in python 3 are not supported by betfairlightweight. What is the appropriate way to call a function with a timer or a function in the future in python 3?

I wanted to implement a Timer function that calls some betfairlightweight functions but apparently Timer and threading functions in python 3 are not supported by betfairlightweight. What is the appropriate way to call a function with a timer or a function in the future in python 3?
